Deidentified_article_title: LETTER TO [ORGANIZATION] AND [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Public housing is a critical resource for low-income people across [ORGANIZATION], especially women, those with disabilities, as well as [LOCATION], Indigenous, and other people of color. It is crucial to ensuring safe and affordable housing for all, as international human rights standards provide. Yet [ORGANIZATION] of devastating budget cuts have forced many public housing residents to live in homes made unsafe by lead paint, mold, and disrepair. Alternatives to Section 9, such as [ORGANIZATION], however, have reduced oversight and protections for residents, and in some cases we have examined in [PERSON], appear to have led to increased evictions.

Deidentified_article_title: LETTER TO [ORGANIZATION] AND [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION] is a Crucial Source of Affordable Housing

Deidentified_article_title: LETTER TO [ORGANIZATION] AND [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Because rents in public housing are capped at 30 percent of a households income, public housing is a critical source of affordable housing for low-income families. In [ORGANIZATION], for example, public housing comprises over half of the homes which are affordable to extremely low-income tenants, or those making less than 30 percent of the area median.1 [ORGANIZATION] has been conducting research on public housing for a forthcoming report, and many residents we interviewed testified to the crucial role public housing has played in their own lives. One resident described how the affordability of public housing enabled her late-grandmother to retire. There is no [STREET] she would have been able to have that quality of life at the end of her life without public housing, she told [ORGANIZATION].

Deidentified_article_title: LETTER TO [ORGANIZATION] AND [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Public housing is uniquely able to provide homes that are permanently affordable.2 Affordability guarantees in other supply-side affordable housing programs, such as [ORGANIZATION] LIHTC and project-based Section 8 housing, typically expire after a number of years. As a result, over 700,000 homes will see their affordability restrictions expire by [ORGANIZATION], placing thousands of families at risk of displacement.3

Deidentified_article_title: LETTER TO [ORGANIZATION] AND [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: [ORGANIZATION] has a forthcoming report about the effects of [ORGANIZATION] in [ORGANIZATION], and our research indicates that the program results in the loss of oversight, accountability, and support mechanisms that are important to protect residents human rights. Data provided to [ORGANIZATION] by the [ORGANIZATION] Housing Authority ORG2 also indicates that some [ORGANIZATION]-converted housing developments have seen an increase in their [ORGANIZATION] eviction rates. Evictions that leave individuals homeless or lead to other violations of human rights violate the human right to housing. Given the vulnerable population public housing serves, increases in evictions raise concerns over human rights.

Deidentified_article_title: Pursuing Desegregation in the PERSON0 Era
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Over [ORGANIZATION], a number of cities and states have been sued and accused of either doing nothing to alleviate segregation or actively promoting it by disproportionately building affordable housing in poor, minority neighborhoods.

Deidentified_article_title: Pursuing Desegregation in the PERSON0 Era
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Other cities have tried to address segregation -- and failed. [ORGANIZATION], for example, after being sued in [ORGANIZATION] over historic patterns of housing discrimination, started offering developers financial incentives to create affordable housing in affluent neighborhoods. But the programs had no takers, according to a [PERSON] report by The [ORGANIZATION] Sun.

Deidentified_article_title: Pursuing Desegregation in the PERSON0 Era
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The county surveyed thousands of residents about their communities and the barriers they faced. A lack of affordable housing was one of the main complaints, said [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION] deputy chief of housing and community development.

Deidentified_article_title: Pursuing Desegregation in the PERSON0 Era
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The county separate from the city of [ORGANIZATION] and other county jurisdictions will develop affordable housing in areas with small minority populations, creating 50 new units and overseeing the lease of up to 128 others over [ORGANIZATION]. With other state and local funding sources, the county hopes to fund as many as 4,795 units in that time, according to [ORGANIZATION]. The county will also counsel households and property owners that allege violations of fair housing laws and create a homeowners fraud prevention program to prevent low-income buyers from being duped.

Deidentified_article_title: Pursuing Desegregation in the PERSON0 Era
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Developers are typically willing to build affordable housing, [ORGANIZATION] said. The pushback tends to come from residents in affluent neighborhoods who take a not in my backyard approach. To counter that, he said, takes a huge education process to convince them that affordable housing developments can blend seamlessly into the neighborhood.

Deidentified_article_title: Pursuing Desegregation in the PERSON0 Era
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The city of [ORGANIZATION], [PERSON], recently completed its segregation report. It found that segregation levels, while moderate, hadnt changed much since [ORGANIZATION] and that black, Asian and Latino residents tended to live in lower-income areas of the city. One factor contributing to segregation was landlords not taking federal Section 8 housing vouchers, the report found. Other factors zoning laws, the location of affordable housing, lending discrimination and a lack of fair housing enforcement.

Deidentified_article_title: Pursuing Desegregation in the PERSON0 Era
Deidentified_paragraph_text: As part of a [ORGANIZATION] plan, the city is focusing on increasing affordable housing stock, housing the homeless, and helping low-income renters cover security deposits.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: Well-designed affordable housing programs are a cost-effective [STREET] to promote racial and class integration without affecting property values, crime rates or taxes, said [ORGANIZATION], a [ORGANIZATION] professor of sociology who coauthored [ORGANIZATION] The Struggle for [ORGANIZATION] in an American Suburb.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: Repeal the [ORGANIZATION] partial overhaul of the ORG1 and use data and community feedback to strengthen it. Deidentified_paragraph_text: Preserve and strengthen tools at [ORGANIZATION] and [ORGANIZATION] to facilitate access to affordable homeownership and rental housing, including the affordable housing goals and Duty to Serve, and strengthen ORG2. This includes preserving and strengthening the affordable housing goals and Duty to Serve, examining the effects of [ORGANIZATION] pricing, ensuring ORG2 continues to offer nondiscriminatory pricing to all families, and giving consumers the ability to choose the type of loan that is best for them. The housing agencies, the [ORGANIZATION]s, and [PERSON] must consider the unequal housing barriers that exist in developing policies, and [PERSON] and the agencies must make the necessary investments to ensure equitable access to housing. This includes regulating the [ORGANIZATION]s as utilities, providing equitable treatment for all lenders regardless of size, serving all housing markets throughout the country, providing a catastrophic government backstop, expanding investments in affordable housing, and maintaining the [ORGANIZATION]s successful multifamily business models. These principles are essential starting points to ensuring equal access to our nations housing market.

Deidentified_paragraph_text: Preserve and create affordable housing for low-income renters and homeowners through grants to states, local communities, and housing nonprofits. Deidentified_article_title: Why Hedge Funds Shouldn't Own the News
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Since these two shadowy financial players increasingly converge, I will refer to all this as hedge fund activity.Dramatic changes in news ownership have been recent and swift. DATE0, hedge funds control one-third of [ORGANIZATION], and all four of the largest local newspaper chains are owned or managed by these poorly regulated financial institutions. Three-quarters of the top 200 newspapers by circulation are owned or controlled by hedge funds.The [ORGANIZATION] dire assessment spotlights the extreme lack of transparency already demonstrated by these companies, and in the context of local news, it has disastrous implications for democracy.The [ORGANIZATION] law enforcement sensitive bulletin on private equity was leaked and published online by a transparency group called [ORGANIZATION], after hackers broke into law enforcement records at a [ORGANIZATION] web development company. The contents of the leak were verified4 by intelligence site ORG2, and the [ORGANIZATION] was reported by ORG3.Noting its assessment was made with high confidence, the [ORGANIZATION] report says that in the long term, criminally complicit investment fund managers likely will expand their money laundering operations as private placement opportunities increase, resulting in continued infiltration of the licit global financial system.The report continuesSpecifically, hedge funds and private equity firms receive funds from entities registered in nations that maintain laws conducive to masking underlying beneficial owners, thereby making it harder for GPE2 financial institutions and regulators to determine the source of funding. Additionally, hedge funds and private equity firms have been used to facilitate transactions in support of fraud, transnational organized crime, and sanctions evasion.The problem is that some of the basic safeguards used to detect money laundering just arent applied to private equity and hedge funds. Of the limited information available about hedge funds, most is general or not publicly reported, the report says, noting that the required [ORGANIZATION], for example, is not public.Furthermore, since many hedge funds and private equity firms are unregistered entities, the [ORGANIZATION] has limited oversight ability, making proactive identification of fraudulent hedge funds difficult, the assessment says. Common anti-money laundering measures that banks and traditional funds operate undersuch as know your customer due diligence programs or providing detailed trading data and company records to the [ORGANIZATION]do not apply to private equity and hedge funds. Your donation keeps this site free and open for all to read. Give what you can...SUPPORT THE PROSPECT6 What Do Hedge Funds Have to Do With Your Local News? DATE0, the largest [ORGANIZATION] newspaper [ORGANIZATION], ORG6, ORG7, and [ORGANIZATION] owned, controlled by, or indebted to hedge funds.Taken together, these chains are [LOCATION] primary source of local news. Under hedge fund stewardship, local newspapers are bleeding staff and resources, even shutting papers down. Much of this shrinkage has been intentionally accelerated by the hedge fund practice of cutting costs to the bone to maximize short-term returnsdemocracy be damned.Its true that newspapers have struggled for [ORGANIZATION] to reinvent themselves in the face of readers turning to social media and online aggregators for information, and losing advertising revenue to the likes of [ORGANIZATION]. But were it not for hedge fund owners bleeding them dry, newspapers could be breaking even or turning modest profits.The [ORGANIZATION] pandemic has accelerated their need to go digital, as print advertising income drops even more. In response to [ORGANIZATION] urgent demand for reliable, fact-checked information, many newspapers are looking to online subscriptions as a growing source of revenue.Most local news outlets are aggressively moving onto digital platforms. But hedge funds, with their emphasis on quick profits and extracting rather than investing cash, are now making that shift nearly impossible.Chains like [ORGANIZATION]0 simply arent investing to expand their online presence, because [ORGANIZATION]1 has made clear it considers it a waste of money. Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: Weve spent a lot of time in this committee talking about affordable housing and the crisis thats hurting so many of our constituents across the country. One possible solution to the crunch in my district is manufactured housing, which can be more than 30 percent cheaper than traditional housing. Nationwide, almost 3 million manufactured homes are anchored in land leased communities, which means that residents own the homes but least the land underneath them. And many of these communities are being purchased by big, outside investors and increasingly, private equity firms. So Id like to talk about how tenants are affected by increased private equity investment in land leased communities.

Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: So we all know that the homes in mobile home parks are truly not mobile and that the residents are effectively a--a captive audience. What Id like to reiterate here is that manufactured homes can be a solution for affordable housing, a great solution, but only if we can address the problem of outside investors buying up MHCs and raising rents to extract as much profit as they can from the people that live there. So we, absolutely, need to address that. We want to make sure that every person in this country has access to a--a nice roof over their head and that their children can grow up in a safe environment.

Deidentified_article_title: [ORGANIZATION]
Deidentified_paragraph_text: We expanded access to early childhood education. We targeted homelessness, and we reduced recidivism in our jails. And we could have done these--these projects without financial partners. But I know that the desire to invest in projects that have more than a monetary return are not just limited to government problems, you see a range of investments in clean energy technologies and social welfare issues, for example. Our state, local, and federal governments and nonprofits dont always have the resources to solve problems by themselves, and I know that firsthand.

Deidentified_article_title: Slick, [ORGANIZATION] Off
Deidentified_paragraph_text: The campaign demonstrated that despite a changing society increasingly consumed by social media and online video, television remains a potent, persuasive force, even for disruptive tech giants like [ORGANIZATION]. The record [ORGANIZATION] campaign spending  which totaled 27.8 million for all measures and candidates  also offers a preview of what is expected to be an even bigger media onslaught [LOCATION], as a presidential election draws more voters to the polls. In [DATE], multiple seats will be up for grabs at the citys ORG1, and at least one likely ballot initiative threatens the soda industry, which has a history of throwing big sums into local elections to protect its bottom line. By [PERSON], more than 6.4 million had been poured into TV advertising alone for five ballot initiatives and three candidate races [LOCATION]ositions A, D, E, F and I, as well as the contests for mayor, sheriff and [ORGANIZATION]. The vast majority of that money went to defeating [LOCATION]osition F2, which tried unsuccessfully to expand regulations on short-term rentals of homes and apartments. The ORG13 campaign, funded chiefly by [ORGANIZATION]-based [ORGANIZATION], outspent proponents on television 45-to-1, buying [TIME] of opposition advertising for [TIME] of [ORGANIZATION] ads, based on a [ORGANIZATION] [ORGANIZATION] review of TV advertising, which included national and local stations. Shaped by national political consultants, the big-money campaigns created an echo chamber, aided by local broadcasters. Superficial TV reporting parroted claims in the ads, which were notable for distorting or obscuring facts, attacking a candidates character or conjuring menacing images of Big Brother intrusions into peoples bedrooms and personal information. Misrepresentations big and small pervaded the airwaves Claims inaccurately attributed to the official ballot initiative text of [LOCATION]osition F An attack on ORG2 challenger [ORGANIZATION], who was seeking to regain his old seat from the supervisor [PERSON] had installed. The ad portrayed the ORG1 former president  and mayoral foe  as an aggressive [TIME] caller A questionable claim that [ORGANIZATION]s 310 million housing bond, [LOCATION]osition A, would not cost taxpayers anything. Campaign ad makers arent interested in accurate sources, but they want those facts in there, they want a newspaper quote, they want some sort of backup information, said [ORGANIZATION], co-author of [ORGANIZATION]. They might cite some sort of voting records, but youre not going to get the exact citation that would let you easily track down the information, he said. Its a feature of our ads  theres too much info in politics [PERSON] to fact-check all of this. To PERSON3, that information overload poses a challenge to democracy. Organized groups are sending out information at light speed, and in a sense this is a crisis of journalism, he said. How to help voters sort through it. Analyzing the Ads The [ORGANIZATION] collaborated with [ORGANIZATION], a [ORGANIZATION]-based nonprofit that catalogs electronic media worldwide, to analyze 27 distinct TV spots that aired on 11 stations during the fall campaign. We looked closely at five [ORGANIZATION] stations that accounted for more than half of the airtime for the ads and virtually all the televised news coverage of the election ORG7, [ORGANIZATION], ORG9, ORG10 and [ORGANIZATION]. Ads also ran on Chinese-language station ORG12 but were not reviewed. All told, [TIME] of ads ran on these five stations from after DATE5 until [ORGANIZATION], compared with a total of [TIME] of TV news coverage  a ratio of about 7-to-1. Of the total ad time, ORG13 dominated with [TIME], compared with [TIME] for the Yes effort  a 76-to-1 imbalance. By far the most contentious citywide issue was [PERSON] by ORG14, the initiative tried to toughen the ordinance, passed and signed in [LOCATION], that legalized short-term rentals and established a system of registration and taxation. Though renters still widely outnumber homeowners in [ORGANIZATION], many from both groups are united in the opportunity to reap windfalls from short-term rentals, even though they may contribute to rising costs and the overall housing crisis. The campaign to defeat [LOCATION]osition F pitted [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION], real estate interests, tech venture capitalist PERSON5 and some labor unions against tenant activists, neighborhood groups, hotel unions and wealthy property owners, who were badly outgunned and outspent on all media. [ORGANIZATION] led the ORG13 television blitz, ponying up 4.7 million in TV buys alone to beat back broader control of its business model, according to city data. The Yes campaign mustered only about 104,000 for television, and about 1.1 million overall. All told, [ORGANIZATION] spent more than 9 million to be victorious. That number has been exceeded only once since [ORGANIZATION] began reliably tracking campaign finances online in [LOCATION] when [PERSON]...pent 11 million to defeat a renewable-energy measure in DATE9. The campaign had all the modern bells and whistles you would expect of an effort backed by a [PERSON] giant, ORG13 consultant [PERSON], co-founder of ORG16, wrote in the online journal ORG17ections7 in [LOCATION]0. Casting doubts on [LOCATION]osition F Crucial to victory were several slick, 30- and [TIME] TV spots that skillfully  if misleadingly  sowed doubts about [LOCATION]osition F. To craft more than a dozen complementary TV ads, [ORGANIZATION] for Everyone  ORG13, funded primarily by [ORGANIZATION], turned to noted Democratic strategist [PERSON] ....8 Based outside [ORGANIZATION], [ORGANIZATION], the firm has deep ties to the party and top Democrats, including Vice President [PERSON], Gov. [PERSON] and state Attorney General [PERSON]0. [PERSON]1 worked on [PERSON]2 [LOCATION]1 campaign against President [PERSON]3. [PERSON]4 sister, [PERSON]5, is the firms executive vice president. [PERSON] has also handled media campaigns for ORG18 and other corporate heavyweights. It boasts that it has not lost a ballot initiative in [LOCATION]2. Following the firms much admired playbook  9 Principles of Winning Campaigns9  ORG13 proponents worked to create uncertainty about the measure before going in for the kill. We start with the simple notion that campaigns cannot move a No to a Yes or vice versa, [PERSON] declared. You must first move initiative voters to undecided. Only then can you persuade them the rest of the [STREET]. Vice President [PERSON]6 has called [PERSON]1 the preeminent storyteller who makes voters want to listen. In [LOCATION]3, a poll by ORG19, which was hired by the ORG13 campaign, showed public opinion was almost evenly divided. In [LOCATION]4, ORG13 cranked up the volume, running [TIME] of ads, about 60 percent on local stations. The Yes campaign was silent, airing not a single spot [LOCATION]5, the [ORGANIZATION] analysis found. The barrage paid off, according to [ORGANIZATION] polling in mid-[LOCATION]4. No led by 16 points. After [LOCATION]7 our No vote jumped to a dramatic double-digit lead while the Yes vote dropped like a rock, [PERSON]s website said. In [LOCATION]. F, we focused on a broad theme that the proposal was just too extreme, [PERSON]7, senior vice president of [PERSON], told the [ORGANIZATION]. Strategically, we had undermined the Yes on [LOCATION]. F before our opponents could react. That made it ultimately impossible for them ever to fully recover or to ever regain the lead. The ORG13 blitz hammered home the idea that the measure was just too extreme, a new threat that would violate peoples privacy, encourage spying on your neighbors and result in thousands of new lawsuits. The ads capitalized on growing concerns about privacy, personal rights and government intrusion following revelations that ORG23 was amassing phone and email data on Americans in its efforts to thwart terrorism. [ORGANIZATION] and his predecessor, Lt. Gov. [PERSON]8, smoothly reinforced the themes that the measure goes too far and is just too extreme. [ORGANIZATION] with five supervisors, the Democratic and Republican parties, [PERSON] and others, they trumped a long list of influential [ORGANIZATION] backers that included Sen. [PERSON]9 former mayor [ORGANIZATION]0 five city supervisors Democratic clubs teachers, nurses and hotel workers unions tenants rights groups and neighborhood associations. The [STREET] people learn is through endorsements, said [ORGANIZATION]1, a political scientist at [ORGANIZATION] State University who specializes in urban politics and voting behavior. People are generally skeptical of ballot propositions if there is opposition. Thats the endorsement thing. Its not the ad, its the endorsements, he added. You can spend a lot of money to make those endorsements obvious, or that conflict obvious. Then people are skeptical and it fails to pass. Leave spying to the movies Beyond endorsements, memorable [PERSON] spots turned to the dark side to cast [LOCATION]osition F as a sinister ORG25 effort to monitor residents bedrooms and create personal dossiers. One depicted a creepy neighbor peering through night-vision-like binoculars at Victorian houses, followed by images of aerial surveillance video and a data scan of a palm print. Lets leave the spying to the movies, not the neighbors, the narrator said over a [ORGANIZATION]3 soundtrack of surf guitar. Another spot showed shadowy fingers on a laptop keyboard as the narrator warned that the initiative would allow the government to collect peoples private information. Voters were never told that the existing ordinance12 already required hosts to register with the [LOCATION] and maintain [LOCATION]8 records of their residency and rentals, thereby compelling them to share certain private information demonstrating primary residency, the number of [DATE] they occupied their unit, and the dates and the duration of each short-term rental. As it stood, [LOCATION]9 ordinance required that the city create a registry of short-term-rental hosts and that the information shall be available for public review to the extent required by law  with one exception to the extent permitted by law, ORG26 shall redact any [ORGANIZATION] names from the records available for public review. [ORGANIZATION] is not alone GPE4, [PERSON], officials may subpoena much more personal information to enforce the citys short-term-rental laws, including phone, tax, vehicle and real estate records. Another notable ad was called Night, featuring the simple imagery of a half-asleep woman between crisp white sheets. What if the government required you to report when youre sleeping in your own home, or even in your own bed? a gravelly male voice narrated over the tune Lullaby and Goodnight. If [LOCATION]. F passes, [ORGANIZATION] will be the only city in the country where residents will be forced to do just that. The ominous warnings in both ads were attributed to the Official Text [ORGANIZATION] Measure F and ORG27  a nonprofit advocacy group listed as an ongoing client of [ORGANIZATION]4, the media buyer for ORG13. MANIPULATION AND MESSAGING The truth, however, was something else. Nowhere in the official ballot text15  which amended the existing code covering short-term rentals  did it require hosts using [ORGANIZATION], [LOCATION] or ORG29 to report when they were sleeping in their own homes or beds. [LOCATION]osition F reiterated the language from the ordinance backed by [ORGANIZATION], approved by supervisors and enacted in [DATE]0 [LOCATION]8 reporting of the number of [DATE] a primary residence was occupied and [DATE]1 it was rented out. No bed checks. Consider that if you go out of town for [DATE]2 or [DATE]3, you are still considered to be legally occupying your home or apartment, even if you were away or let friends or family occupy it in your absence. Certainly, not all [ORGANIZATION] residents read the official ballot text or the new ordinance that took effect [DATE]4. The initiative just went further, too far for a majority of voters who turned out. Some of the most controversial provisions called for cutting [DATE]5 short-term rentals from [DATE]6 to [DATE]7 banning use of in-law units tightening registration and reporting, and bolstering the neighbor complaint process and enforcement by bringing [ORGANIZATION] and its rivals into the process. Additionally, residents would have needed permission to operate as a bed and breakfast for rentals beyond [DATE]7 [DATE]. The ORG13 campaign apparently persuaded many voters to believe that it would be the ballot measure that would make already existing provisions law. And [ORGANIZATION] disguised two of its biggest concerns, which it had fought to keep out of the ordinance [ORGANIZATION] signed in [LOCATION]. Not surprisingly, the No campaign did not point out that the [LOCATION]osition F would have required [ORGANIZATION] and its competitors to closely monitor listings and remove illegal units and those that had been rented out for more than [DATE]7 [DATE] over [PERSON]6 [PERSON]0. Failure to do so could have resulted in fines up to 1,000 a day per listing, potentially costing [ORGANIZATION] and the others tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars. [LOCATION]osition F also would have cleared the [STREET] for residents and other interested parties  neighbors and landlords among them  to directly sue [ORGANIZATION] and its competitors, which under the current law can be done only by [ORGANIZATION]0. The opposition took no chances on finding the most potent message. Yes ads were also created to test against focus groups watching No spots, said [ORGANIZATION]5, of [PERSON]. There was one ad we produced to test for the yes side that would have likely won the race for them had they aired it, he said, without revealing the ads content. Our opponents greatest strength was the simplicity of their message  the housing crisis  and, frankly, they swung and missed. The [ORGANIZATION] campaign mustered only one TV ad. It claimed that illegal [ORGANIZATION] hotels were evicting thousands of GPE6 from their homes and causing rents to skyrocket, citing news articles in the [ORGANIZATION] Examiner and [ORGANIZATION]2. Neither article contained the ads wording, however, and its claims have not been established conclusively. Nearly three-quarters of [ORGANIZATION] units are covered by rent control, and it is illegal for landlords to evict tenants and begin renting to visitors. Although evictions jumped [PERSON]1, [ORGANIZATION]3 reported, it is not known whether the units were subsequently rented out to visitors or to new long-term tenants at much higher market rates. In a [PERSON]2 report, the [ORGANIZATION] Budget and [ORGANIZATION] office estimated that [ORGANIZATION] listings may have been responsible for removing between 925 and 1,960 housing units from the residential market, based on data from [PERSON]3 and [PERSON]4. That could represent between 11 percent and 23.2 percent of the citys vacant housing units, the report said, noting that its estimates and conclusions were conservative and understate the full short-term rental market by an unknown amount. Regardless of the accuracy of the ads claims, it was virtually invisible compared with the No onslaught. For all of [PERSON]5, the Yes ad aired a total of only [TIME]. Ultimately, the ORG13 ads epitomized the art of political persuasion and spin. Night earned industry recognition and awards18 for the campaign team  [PERSON], [LOCATION], [ORGANIZATION] media buyer [ORGANIZATION]6, campaign manager [ORGANIZATION]7 and senior adviser [ORGANIZATION]8, [ORGANIZATION]s head of global policy and public affairs and an adviser in the [ORGANIZATION]9 [PERSON]1 [ORGANIZATION]. TV was not the only vehicle the campaign used to drum up opposition to F, however. We sent 16 pieces of mail to a universe of approximately 100,000 households and made sure it mirrored the content of the TV ads, wrote PERSON30, of [ORGANIZATION]-based ORG16.
